description: Continuation of Chemistry 101. The second term stresses the thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms. It includes special topics in chemistry.
name: GENERAL CHEMISTRY II

values.comments:
General Chemistry II, CHEM 102, is a continuation of the CHEM 101 syllabus. The topics covered include thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, reaction rates and mechanisms, and other special topics in Chemistry.

Course material was tested using the ‘OWL’ system, which some students regarded as “helpful”. The course was seen as difficult and “quite time-consuming” because of extensive assignments from the OWL program. The exam structure also drew several complaints with students blaming it for poor grades. But overall, students agreed that they learned a suitable amount of information from this course and the assigned readings were usually valuable. 

Professor Topp was not able to greatly stimulate the students’ interest in the course material where there were some complaints about his presentation skills. However, students conceded that the “demonstrations were particularly helpful”. Although Professor Topp appeared very knowledgeable, the topics he covered in his lectures did not necessarily correspond with the topics tested in the “tricky” exams. Students also described those exams as “far too long” and “not really encouraging when you know beforehand that you will never finish”. 

This course was not recommended for non-majors although it does fulfill the Physical World Sector requirement. The only pre-requisite is CHEM 101 and the course must be supplemented with the co-requisite lab CHEM 054.

Course material was tested using the ‘OWL’ system, which some students regarded as “helpful”. The course was seen as difficult and “quite time-consuming” because of extensive assignments from the OWL program. The exam structure also drew several complaints with students blaming it for poor grades. But overall, students agreed that they learned a suitable amount of information from this course and the assigned readings were usually valuable. 

Professor Topp was not able to greatly stimulate the students’ interest in the course material where there were some complaints about his presentation skills. However, students conceded that the “demonstrations were particularly helpful”. Although Professor Topp appeared very knowledgeable, the topics he covered in his lectures did not necessarily correspond with the topics tested in the “tricky” exams. Students also described those exams as “far too long” and “not really encouraging when you know beforehand that you will never finish”. 

This course was not recommended for non-majors although it does fulfill the Physical World Sector requirement. The only pre-requisite is CHEM 101 and the course must be supplemented with the co-requisite lab CHEM 054.

This course is a continuation of Chemistry 101. This second semester of general chemistry stresses the thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms. Special topics in chemistry are also covered. 

As far as the course itself, one student felt that “lectures were good but overall coming to class was an extremely stressful experience.” As far as the teaching environments were concerned, several students felt that this lecture was “just like high school.” Other students felt that the course was “difficult” yet “informative.” 

One student criticized Professor Wehbi’s teaching style, mentioning that he was “very stern, and sometimes quite rude to students in lecture.” Another student stated that it “would have been good if there was a professor-led discussion or review session every week for those who need a little subject reinforcement.” Students repeatedly criticized Professor Wehbi’s teaching style, suggesting that he “should respect [the] 50-minute time limit of class out of respect for other professors” and that he “is difficult, bordering on mean.” Another student stated frankly that Professor Wehbi “does not know how to relate to students… [his] teaching skips around, [and he] expects student to know material he has not taught.” One student felt that Professor Wehbi \"has terrible communication with students [and] creates a toxic classroom environment.” 

One student mentioned that as far as the coursework itself, “the book was a far better way to learn the material.” Another student felt that he felt prepared for his MCAT as a result of having attended Professor Wehbi’s lecture. The general consensus among students in this section of Chemistry 102 was that “exams were inconsistent…not a reflection of knowledge…longer than physically possible.” Specifically, one student expressed that they “wish[ed] that the assigned problems were either form the textbook or old exams so that there would be more time to practice.” Another student mentioned that “the exams test only the student’s ability to write quickly, not their understanding and application of the material.”
